etymologies: late Middle English: from Italian, Spanish, and medieval Latin, from Arabic al-jabr ‘the reunion of broken parts’, ‘bone-setting’, from jabara ‘reunite, restore’. The original sense, ‘the surgical treatment of fractures’, probably came via Spanish, in which it survives; the mathematical sense comes from the title of a book, ‘ilm al-jabr wa'l-muqābala ‘the science of restoring what is missing and equating like with like’, by the mathematician al-Ḵwārizmī (see algorithm)

definitions: the part of mathematics in which letters and other general symbols are used to represent numbers and quantities in formulae and equations

examples.text: courses in algebra, geometry, and Newtonian physics

shortDefinitions: part of mathematics in which letters and other general symbols are used to represent numbers and quantities

definitions: a system of algebra based on given axioms.
shortDefinitions: system of algebra based on given axioms
